reward.translation[0].definitions[0].def: something that you get because you have done something good or helpful or have worked hard
reward.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: The school has a system of rewards and punishments to encourage good behaviour.
Parents often give their children rewards for passing exams.
reward.translation[0].definitions[1].def: money that is offered to people for helping the police to solve a crime or catch a criminal
reward.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: A reward of $20,000 has been offered.
a reward for information leading to the capture of the murderers
reward.translation[0].note_box[0].headin: – Meaning 1: something that you get because you have done something good or helpful or have worked hard
reward.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: ADJECTIVES
great/big/high
The rewards for those who invested at the right time are high.
Some athletes took drugs because the rewards were great and they thought they could get away with it.
little reward
They have to work very hard for very little reward.
financial/economic reward
It’s a difficult job, but the financial rewards are considerable.
I’m not doing it for monetary reward.
material rewards
They think money and material rewards are more important than quality of life.
tangible rewards
The prize motivates people by offering them the prospect of a tangible reward for their efforts.
rich rewards
Top athletes can expect rich rewards if they win.
personal reward
I admire people who help the poor for no personal reward.
get/receive your reward
If you work hard, you will get your reward.
reap rewards
She is now reaping the rewards of all her hard work.
bring rewards
Winning the title brings huge financial rewards.
deserve a reward
The team have worked really hard and deserve some reward.
reward.translation[0].note_box[1].headin: – Meaning 2: money that is offered to people for helping the police to solve a crime or catch a criminal
reward.translation[0].note_box[1].sectio: The store has offered a £500 reward for information leading to a conviction.
He contacted the police, hoping to claim the reward money offered by the bank.
The $100,000 reward Levitz’s family offered in the days after her disappearance still stands.
Despite a substantial reward being offered, the painting has never been found.
'Anyone who gives me the information that leads to an arrest will get the reward money, ' he repeated.
reward.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to give something to someone because they have done something good or helpful or have worked for it
reward.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: The club’s directors rewarded him with a free season ticket.
She wanted to reward the cleaners for their efforts.
He gave the children some chocolate to reward them for behaving well.
reward.translation[2].definitions[0].def: something that you receive because you have done something good or helpful
reward.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: Officials were often posted abroad as a reward for loyal service.
reward.translation[2].definitions[1].def: money that you earn for doing a job or providing a service
reward.translation[2].definitions[1].exa: Working as a lawyer can bring big financial rewards.
Her success has brought her little commercial reward.
the economic rewards that come with tourism
reward.translation[2].definitions[2].exa: Investors are hoping for big rewards.
It has reaped huge rewards (=gained them) in the stock market.
reward.translation[2].definitions[3].def: an amount of money offered to someone in return for some information about something
reward.translation[2].definitions[3].exa: The bank is offering a £100,000 reward for information.
reward.translation[3].definitions[0].def: to give someone something such as money because they have done something good or helpful
reward.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: a bonus system that rewards workers who meet targets
The best managers are rewarded with greater responsibility.
